of the times it's a word like balance
ski-jumping is about two opposing
objectives on the ramp speed is key so
Jessica Jerome positions her body like a
dart to glide down the hill but in
flight she uses her body like a sail
catching as much air as possible to stay
aloft
Jerome tries to keep her center of
gravity just in front of the middle of
her foot I am usually trying not to keep
my face too high because then my
shoulders get tense and everything gets
crunched up you want your arms to be by
your side not to like stiff squeezing
you but obviously not hanging so just a
relaxed aerodynamic position your the
end of the run the ramp begins to curve
creating g-forces that are twice

run position and you feel the curve
coming instead of moving like forward or

straight down and straight back up
you're trying to feel the natural
compression on your body while trying to
maintain that balance in the exact same
spot the end of the ramp flattens out
releasing the jumpers from the g-forces
just before takeoff when they're moving
at about 60 miles per hour that is when
you begin your move as we call it which
is the transition into the flight in
your in run position you're like a
spring and you're coiled up and then you
want to extend we try to think of it as
not as a jump or one explosive move we
try to think of it as a long push the
idea is to move your body and your hips
up and out you already have the speed
from the inrun you're trying to gain

instantly if you've done everything

float
you
Jerome's skis are at a 45 degree angle
to maximize the surface area of her body
and her skis your skis are going to be
in the V position you don't want them
too wide or too narrow you want your
skis to be under you and in control you
want them to be flat from the profile
your body and your skis looks like an
airplane wing and they act as a wing as
well causing more pressure beneath her
helping Jerome to stay aloft you're
looking out past where you want to land
usually you want to be flying with the
hill for as long as you can and you want

down distance is not the only metric in
ski jumping style counts - especially on
the landing you want to have a good
balanced landing one foot in from the
other about a foot distance in between
the two feet not wobbling not arms all
over the place
the idea is to do everything the same
